intro: Quiina tessmannii, commonly known as the desert quina, is a shrub native to the arid regions of South America. It belongs to the family Geraniaceae and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and waxy, elliptical leaves. The plant is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments with minimal water availability. Its leaves contain compounds that have been historically used for their medicinal properties. Quiina tessmannii plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native habitat and is of interest for its potential in phytoremediation.
